page.title: 01The Area of our study.
page.content: Today it was bright and sunny we walked to the top of the hill behind St.Mary's Church ,Ashbury to see the view of the study area.We found two fossils in a corn field in the chalk rock.When we looked across at the slopes of the coombs,they looked rough and bumpy but when you look down the hill all the fields of the vale are flat and then it goes up hill again. The farmers donot grow crops on the steep combs slopes because a tractor would roll over. The coombs are made of chalk they are valleys formed by water a long time ago, there is no water there now.If left for sheep to feed off it can grow many kinds of wild flowers and butterflies such as the common blue,and chalk hill blue,and brown argus.Some grasses are called up right broome,blue moor grass.
